2.text: “Should this stream of words go unanswered and such a speaker be vindicated?

3.text: Should your babbling put others to silence? Will you scoff without rebuke?

4.text: You have said, ‘My doctrine is sound, and I am pure in Your sight.’

5.text: But if only God would speak and open His lips against you,

6.text: and disclose to you the secrets of wisdom, for true wisdom has two sides. Know then that God exacts from you less than your iniquity deserves.

7.text: Can you fathom the deep things of God or discover the limits of the Almighty?

8.text: They are higher than the heavens—what can you do? They are deeper than Sheol—what can you know?

9.text: Their measure is longer than the earth and wider than the sea.

10.text: If He comes along to imprison you, or convenes a court, who can stop Him?

11.text: Surely He knows the deceit of men. If He sees iniquity, does He not take note?

12.text: But a witless man can no more become wise than the colt of a wild donkey can be born a man!

13.text: As for you, if you direct your heart and lift up your hands to Him,

14.text: if you put away the iniquity in your hand, and allow no injustice to dwell in your tents,

15.text: then indeed you will lift up your face without blemish; you will stand firm and unafraid.

16.text: For you will forget your misery, recalling it only as waters gone by.

17.text: Your life will be brighter than noonday; its darkness will be like the morning.

18.text: You will be secure, because there is hope, and you will look around and lie down in safety.

19.text: You will lie down without fear, and many will court your favor.

20.text: But the eyes of the wicked will fail, and escape will elude them; they will hope for their last breath.”
